questions.text: A 22-year-old male developed pigmentation over the upper chest for the last 2 years as shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Becker nevus The given clinical picture is of Becker’s nevus. It is an acquired hyperpigmented nevu s preferentially occurs in the scapular region. It is androgen dependent: Males> Females It becomes more prominent in adolescence. Hypertrichosis is often associated. Treatment: Alexandrite Laser

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Drug reaction: Drug reactions occur following intake of a drug. It can either present as a fixed drug reaction or drug-induced hypomelanosis. Drug induced hypermelanosis: Amiodarone Tetracyclines Chloroquine Clofazimine Phenytoin Anti-neoplasticism drugs: Bleomycin, busulfan, cyclophosphamide, etc Psychotropic drugs: Trifluoperazine, imipramine Drugs causing fixed drug eruptions: NSAIDS Cotrimoxazole Tetracyclines Carbamazepine Metronidazole Option C . Postinflammatory hyperpigmentation: It is a temporary condition that follows injury (burn) or infection or dermatitis. It is aka acquired melanosis. Occur in dark-skinned individuals and is more common in persons with Fitzpatrick skin types IV, V, and VI, especially types IV and V. Hyperpigmentation may result from the following two mechanisms: Increased epidermal pigmentation via increased melanocyte activity Dermal melanosis from melanin dropout from the epidermis into the dermis Features: Lesions of hyperpigmentation tend to be tan to brown and may have a gray hue , caused by dermal melanin. Located at the site of the original disease after it has healed. Treatment: Sunscreen to minimize darkening and cosmetic camouflage. Option D .Congenital melanocytic Nevus: It is a proliferation of benign melanocytes that are present at birth or develop shortly after birth Present as single or multi-shaded, round or oval-shaped pigmented patches Congenital nevi usually enlarge as the child grows but they may sometimes become smaller and less obvious with time Giant melanocytic naevi are associated with increased risk of developing cutaneous melanoma.

questions.text: Identify the nerve thickened here in a leprosy patient.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Greater auricular nerve The given picture shows thickened Great auricular nerve Well-defined, raised outer border of a TT lesion ending abruptly; while the inner margin is ill-defined, sloping and waning toward the center. Enlarged, nodular great auricular nerve and involvement of ear is noted Routinely palpated nerves "of predilection" in leprosy: Great auricular nerve Ulnar nerve Radial cutaneous nerve Median nerve Lateral popliteal nerve Posterior tibial nerve

Extraedge:

Features of nerve involvement in Leprosy: Enlarged, thickened nerves Sensory component is affected first . (pain and temperature> position and vibration ) Autonomic dysfunction is always present in severe nerve damage . Motor nerve involvement: Ulnar = Peroneal > Median Preserved tendon reflexes

Table:

#MANTRA Characteristics of leprosy based on Ridley Joplin Classification: Feature TT BT BB BL LL Number of lesion 1 to 3 Up to 10 10 to 30 Numerous Innumerable Characteristic Saucer right side up Satellite lesion Inverted saucer/ Swiss cheese appearance Almost symmetrical distribution Perfect Symmetrical Distribution Sensation Absent Markedly diminished Moderately diminished Slightly diminished May be normal Nerve involvement Single nerve Asymmetric enlargement of few nerves Asymmetric involvement of several nerves Almost symmetrical nerve involvement Symmetrical involvement. Glove and stocking anesthesia Split skin smear- bacteriology Negative Negative or scanty Moderate no. Of bacilli Large no. Of bacilli Plenty of bacilli. Globi is seen. Lepromin reactivity Strong positive Weak positive Weak positive or Negative Negative Negative Histopathology findings Tuberculoid granuloma present. Grenz zone is absent . Few tuberculoid granuloma. Grenz zone presents ut onion an appearance on the transverse a section of nerves. Less prominent tuberculoid granule a and more prominent Grenz zone. Small globi seen. Prominent Grenz zone. Cut onion appearance as more prominent. Foam cells are seen. The most prominent Grenz zone. Expansive and loose granulomas. Globi present. Nerves are minimally involved.

options.label: B

options.text: Non-keratinised, submucosal layer, absent minor salivary gland

questions.correct_answer: A. Keratinised, submucosal layer, minor salivary gland
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Keratinised, submucosal layer, minor salivary gland The hard palate is composed of keratinized epithelium with submucosal layer and presence of minor salivary glands. Region Covering Epithelium Lamina propria Submucosa Lips: Vermilion zone Thin, ortho keratinized, stratified squamous epithelium Numerous narrow papillae; capillary loops close to surface in papillary layer Mucosa firmly attached to underlying muscle; some sebaceous glands in vermilion border, minor salivary glands and fat in intermediate zone Lips: Intermediate zone Thin, parakeratinized, stratified squamous epithelium Long irregular papillae; elastic and collagen fibers in connective tissue No distinct layer, mucosa firmly attached by collagen fibers to cementum and periosteum of alveolar process (mucoperiosteum) Masticatory mucosa gingiva Thick (250 um), ortho keratinized or parakeratinized, stratified squamous epithelium often showing stippled surface Long, narrow papillae, dense collagenous connective tissue; long capillary loops with numerous anastomoses Dense collagenous connective tissue attaching mucosa to periosteum (mucoperiosteum) fat and minor salivary glands are packed into connective tissue in regions where mucosa overlies lateral palatine neurovascular bundles Hard palate Thick, ortho keratinized (parakeratinized, in parts), stratified squamous epithelium thrown into transverse palatine ridges (rugae) Long papillae; thick, dense collagenous tissue, especially under rugae; moderate vascular supply with short capillary loops No distinct layer; mucosa is bound to connective tissue surrounding musculature of tongue Specialized mucosa Dorsal surface of tongue Thick, keratinized, and non-keratinized, stratified squamous epithelium forming three types of papillae, some bearing taste buds Long papillae; minor salivary glands in posterior portion; rich innervations, particularly near taste buds; capillary plexus in papillary layer, large vessels lying deeper

Solution:

VZV Shingles/ Herpes zoster occurs in secondary infection with Varicella zoster virus e reactivation of latent varicella zoster from dorsal root ganglion after primary infection- chicken pox

Highyeild:

Characteristics: Unilateral lesion Dermatomal involvement- most common T3 to L3 spinal segment Mucous membrane within the Derma tome is affected Painful, grouped vesicles over red base Triggers for herpes zoster include Emotional stress Use of medications (immunosuppressants) Acute or chronic illness Exposure to the virus Presence of a malignancy Complication: Post Herpetic neuralgia Treatment: Amitriptyline, pregabalin, gabapentin Antiviral for painful zoster- High dose acyclovir started as early as possible 800 mg 5 times/day for 1 week

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. HSV: HSV 1 causes vesicular eruptions above diaphragm and HSV 2 causes genital herpes. Option C. HPV: It causes warts Option D. CMV: It causes fever, hepatosplenomegaly with cervical lymphadenopathy

Extraedge:

Herpes zoster ophthalmicus: Nerve involved: Frontal branch of ophthalmic nerve (V1) Vesicles present over tip/side of nose = corneal involvement present Herpes zoster oticus: Aka Ramsay hunt syndrome Geniculate ganglion is involved Vesicles over the external auditory canal I/L facial nerve palsy and otalgia present.

questions.text: Virus of H. Zoster resides in :
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Posterior root ganglion Varicella zoster virus remains latent in the posterior root ganglion after primary infection- chicken pox. Shingles/ Herpes zoster It occurs in secondary infection with Varicella zoster virus e reactivation of latent varicella zoster from dorsal root ganglion after primary infection- chicken pox Characteristics: Unilateral lesion Dermatomal involvement- most common T3 to L3 spinal segment Mucous membrane within the Dermatome is affected Painful, grouped vesicles over red base Triggers for herpes zoster include Emotional stress Use of medications (immunosuppressants) Acute or chronic illness Exposure to the virus Presence of a malignancy Complication: Post Herpetic neuralgia Treatment: Amitriptyline, pregabalin, gabapentin Antiviral for painful zoster- High dose acyclovir started as early as possible 800 mg 5 times/day for 1 week

Highyeild:

Herpes zoster ophthalmicus: Nerve involved: Frontal branch of ophthalmic nerve (V1) Vesicles present over tip/side of nose = corneal involvement present Herpes zoster oticus: Aka Ramsay hunt syndrome Geniculate ganglion is involved Vesicles over the external auditory canal I/L facial nerve palsy and otalgia present.

questions.text: A child has a rash on their elbow as shown below with a family history of asthma. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Atopic dermatitis The given clinical picture of the child with a history of asthma in the family is suggestive of Atopic dermatitis. Atopic dermatitis: It is classified as an endogenous eczema triggered by exogenous agents.

Highyeild:

ATOPIC DERMATITIS Key diagnostic criteria: Hanfin and Rajka Pruritus- hallmark Rash on face, extensors, or both in infants and young children Lichenification in flexural areas in older children Tendency toward chronic or chronically relapsing dermatitis Personal or family history of atopic disease: asthma, allergic rhinitis, atopic dermatitis Other Common Findings: Skin features: Dryness Ichthyosis Pityriasis alba White dermatographism (white line appears on the skin within 1 minute of being stroked with a blunt instrument) Head-light sign : periorbital, perioral and perinasal area is spared Ocular features: Dennie-Morgan folds (accentuated lines or grooves below the margin of the lower eyelid) Allergic shiners (darkening beneath the eyes) Conjunctivitis Keratoconus Anterior subcapsular cataracts

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B . Contact dermatitis: It refers to a group of skin disorders in which the skin reaction is due to direct contact with the causative agent.It may affect any area of the body and may be any shape (linear, round, polygonal, irregular). Option C. Allergic dermatitis: It is a form of dermatitis/eczema caused by an allergic reaction to a material, called an allergen, in contact with the skin. The allergen is harmless to people that are not allergic to it. Allergic contact dermatitis is also called contact allergy. Option D . Seborrheic dermatitis: It is a common, chronic, or relapsing form of eczema/dermatitis that mainly affects the sebaceous gland-rich regions of the scalp, face, and trunk. There are infantile and adult forms of seborrhoeic dermatitis.

questions.text: Warthin Finkeldey cells are seen in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Measles Warthin–Finkeldey cell is a type of giant multinucleate cell found in hyperplastic lymph nodes early in the course of measles and also in HIV-infected individuals , as well as in Kimura disease , and more rarely in a number of neoplastic (e.g. lymphoma) and non-neoplastic lymph node disorders. Their origin is uncertain, but they have previously been shown to stain with markers similar to those of follicular dendritic cells, including CD21. Findings under a light microscope, these cells consist of a large, grape-like cluster of nuclei.

Highyeild:

Measles Cause: Measles (rubeola) virus Incubation period: 8 to 12 days Features: Characterised by a typical prodrome of fever, malaise, conjunctivitis, Coryza, and cough Koplik’s spot: Peculiar spots: Viral enanthem, present on the buccal mucosa and are considered a pathognomonic of measles. Usual location of Koplik's spot: Near second molars. Measles rash: Appears after 4 days of fever. Starts behind the ear and spreads downwards. The rash disappears 8 days after the fever leaving brownish pigments. HPE: Warthin finkeldey giant cells in background of paracortical hyperplasia Complications: Most common acute complication: Otitis media Most common chronic complication: Bronchopneumonia SSPE : Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis Treatment: IV fluids/ oral fluids Vit A

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Other options: Option B . Mumps: Histological examination of the parotid gland may show characteristic intracytoplasmic inclusions, Option C . Rubella: Shows characteristic intranuclear inclusions. Option D . Yellow fever: Cowdry A intranuclear inclusions are seen.

Table:

#MANTRA Inclusion bodies Intracytoplasmic Henderson Peterson Molluscum (Pox virus) Negri bodies Rabies Guarneri bodies Vaccinia Paschen bodies Varicella Bollinger bodies Fowl pox Borrel bodies Fowl pox Intranuclear Cowdry A Herpes, yellow fever Cowdry B Adenovirus, poliovirus

questions.text: An anaerobe causing multiple abscesses with discharging sinuses, demonstrating sulfur granules in pus is used to diagnose:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Actinomycetes The given findings of multiple abscesses with discharging sinuses with sulfur granules in pus is suggestive of Mycetoma/ Maduromycosis. Among the given options, Actinomycetes is the causative organism of actinomycetoma. It is a localized, chronic, subcutaneous infection Occupation: usually in farmers Earliest stage: firm, painless nodule but with time papules and pustules, which break down to form draining sinuses, appear on the skin surface. Can extend to underlying bones and joints giving rise to periostitis, osteomyelitis, and arthritis and can produce bony deformity Discharge: Purulent or seropurulent HPE: Actinomycosis shows Sulfur granules: Eosinophilic amorphous material with club-shaped configuration Treatment : Dapsone + Streptomycin/Rifampicin, radical surgery

Highyeild:

Difference: Eumycetoma Actinomycetoma Slowly invasive Rapidly invasive Late presentation Early presentation No pus Pus present Black/brown granules yellowish-white granules Granules 4 to 5 microns in size, in clusters Granules <1 micron, single Gram-negative, GMS PAS positive Gram positive, GMS PAS negative Responds to itraconazole, amphoB Responds to Sulfonamide, doxycycline

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B . Nocardia: It can also cause similar clinical features but the characteristic sulfur granules are not present. Option C and D: Salmonella and Tularemia are bacterial infections that do not typically cause abscesses with discharging sinuses.

questions.text: Cutis marmorata occurs due to exposure to:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cold temperature Cutis marmorata: It is the name given to the mottling of the skin seen in many normal children. It is a physiologic vasospastic response to cold exposure and disappears on warming, whereas true livedo reticularis remains.

Table:

#MANTRA Common findings in Newborn

questions.text: Which of the following condition is NOT caused by Parvovirus B19?

options.label: B
options.text: Aplastic anemia in sickle cell disease

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Roseola infantum Roseola infantum: Cause: HHV 6 Characteristics: Usually seen in children <2 years 3-day fever (causing a tonic-clonic febrile seizure in this child) Blanching, maculopapular, non-pruritic rash Rash appears mainly on the trunk but may spread to the face and extremities. Associated with cervical, postauricular, and/or occipital lymphadenopathy. Nagayama spots Treatment: self-limiting

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B, C, D: Aplastic anemia, fetal hydrous, and erythema infectiosum are caused by Parvovirus B19.

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: Genital warts are caused by which virus?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Human papilloma Genital warts are caused by Human papillomavirus. Warts: Cause: HPV infection- DNA virus Warts can be classified as Anogenital warts: Cause: Low fish HPV- 6,11 Characteristics: Large malodorous masses which may form on vulvar and perianal skin Some lesions are flat, though more conspicuous than plane warts elsewhere, generally on non‐mucosal surfaces such as the penile shaft, pubic skin, perianal skin and groins HPE: Shows extreme acanthosis and papillomatosis Horny layer is parakeratotic Treatment of HPV infection: Topical lactic acid, salicylic acid Electrocautery Cryotherapy

Highyeild:

Condyloma accuminata condyloma lata caused by HPV 6>11 Treponema pallidum- Secondary syphilis Easily bleeds on touch No bleeding Rough, verrucous, dry flat and moist soft, pedunculated induration, sessile Dark ground examination: Negative positive Treatment: Podophyllum resin 25% in alcohol Penicillin

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . Herpes simplex: Causes genital ulcers which are painful. Option C . Cytomegalovirus: Can cause genital ulcer but not warts Option D . Varicella zoster: Causes chicken pox and shingles.

Extraedge:

HPV strains Disease HPV type associated with the disease Cutaneous 1,2 Plantar Wart 2,1 Common Wart 3,10 Flat Wart 7,2 Butcher's wart Genital 16 (Genital) 2, 3, 4, 16 (Extragenital) Bowen's disease (intraepithelial neoplasm) 2, 3, 5, 8, 9 Epidermodysplasia verruciformis (full skin 10, 12, 14, 15, 17 thickness wart can become squamous cell cancer) 6, 11 Condylomata acuminata (venereal or genital warts) Intraepithelial neoplasms Low grade 6, 11 6, 11 High grade 16, 18 Respiratory papillomatosis (transmitted from mother to baby) 6, 11
